Award.AwardTitle: Role of Cl2O and Other "Overlooked Oxidants" as Halogenating Agents

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: A. Lynn Roberts
Proposal Number: CBET-1067391
Institution: Johns Hopkins University
Title: Role of Cl2O and Other "Overlooked Oxidants" as Halogenating Agents

Conventional wisdom has it that HOCl serves as the principal ?active? chlorinating agent in solutions of free available chlorine (FAC), widely used to disinfect drinking water and wastewater. Likewise, HOBr is almost invariably believed to represent ?the? active brominating agent. Although other species (such as Cl2O, Cl2, BrCl, BrOCl, and Br2O) are known to occur as minor constituents of FAC, they are generally believed to be present at concentrations so low as to be negligible. This overlooks the fact that minor constituents can dominate reaction rates if their inherent reactivity outweighs their lesser abundance. Results recently published by the PI?s group demonstrate that several ?overlooked? halogenating agents may force revision of this paradigm. The PI hypothesizes they could play critical roles in the rate-limiting steps for ?slow? formation of the disinfection byproducts (DBPs) that predominate in distribution systems. The speciation of Cl2O, Cl2, BrCl, Br2O, and BrOCl differs from that of HOCl/OCl- or HOBr/OBr-. Their existence could have profound implications on our understanding of the fundamental processes that govern the rates of DBP generation. For example, [Cl2O] will be proportional to [HOCl]2. To the extent that Cl transfer from Cl2O to an organic compound factors into the rate of DBP formation, the kinetics will not be first order in [HOCl] (and, hence, in [FAC] at constant pH). This calls into question the utility of ?apparent? rate coefficients and intrinsic second-order rate coefficients previously reported in the literature. A dependence on [Cl2O] implies that chlorination rates of compounds that themselves lack acid-base speciation should exhibit a (-2)nd order dependence on [H+] at pH above the pKa of HOCl. Finally, the existence of BrCl implies that rates of bromination will increase with [Cl-], and the high reactivity of BrOCl implies that rates of bromination will increase with [FAC] at constant [Br-]. These results could force reconsideration of water treatment practices: the PI?s calculations indicate that the chloride content of FeCl3 commonly added as a coagulant could increase chlorination rates more than tenfold.

The research team intends to examine the kinetics of reaction(s) of an array of organic compounds, with an emphasis on species hypothesized to play a role in the rate of ?slow? DBP generation. They will carefully model the influence of solution conditions on the rate of parent compound loss and reaction product formation, including important DBPs. The suite of target compounds will also include partially halogenated species whose further halogenation has been proposed to represent rate-limiting steps in DBP formation. Finally, undergraduate and high school researchers, working in collaboration with a PhD student, will examine the influence of solution conditions ? especially [FAC] and [Cl-] as a function of pH ? on the rate of DBP formation on chlorination (or bromination) of natural organic matter. The results could assist in formulating improved recommendations for strategies to reduce DBP generation, thereby protecting public health.

Beyond the advancement of scientific discovery, graduate and undergraduate training, and public health aspects of this work, the project will enable K-12 outreach activities, and will broaden the participation of underrepresented groups. Specifically, this project will allow the PI to offer research internships (summer plus ensuing academic year) to students from Baltimore Polytechnic Institute, Baltimore?s magnet science, math, and engineering public high school. Such interns will work closely with undergraduate and PhD student participants, fostering in all participants an appreciation of diverse learning perspectives. Finally, the PI will continue her practice of engaging 5th-7th graders in environmental research by mentoring the research projects required as part of the FIRST Lego League (FLL) annual robotics challenge. Recent projects have included experiments at Johns Hopkins University related to carbon sequestration and research on self-composting toilets.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The intellectual merit of this research centered on identifying the most important agents responsible for the chlorination and bromination of organic compounds. Although conventional wisdom dictated that hypochlorous acid, HOCl (in solutions of free available chlorine, FAC) represented “the” most important chlorinating agent, our findings disproved this tenet by demonstrating that several minor species can (in many situations, and especially at pH values less than ~ 6-7) play dominant roles. Similarly, in solutions containing free bromine, we found that three minor species represent underappreciated brominating agents. These findings were based on detailed studies of the kinetics of chlorination or bromination of ten organic compounds as a function of pH, [FAC] and chloride ion concentration [Cl–]: although HOCl and HOBr may represent the most abundant chlorinating and brominating agents in solutions of free available chlorine and bromine, their modest reactivity limits their roles as halogenating agents to pH values greater than approximately 7. Although the chemical species Cl2, Cl2O, BrCl, and BrOCl are present at only trace concentrations, their much greater inherent reactivity can contribute to their predominance as halogenating agents, especially at pH < 6, at modest to high [Cl–], and at the FAC concentrations likely to be encountered in laboratory settings (from which rate coefficients are most often determined). These minor chlorine species are particularly important in the chlorination of organic compounds of modest reactivity, hypothesized to be responsible for the major fraction of regulated disinfection byproducts (DBPs) generated in distribution systems. One important result of our discoveries is to highlight the importance of Cl– as a halogenation catalyst: even the low concentrations contributed by employing Cl– salts such as FeCl3 during drinking water treatment can contribute sufficient Cl– to substantially increase halogenation rates. Another is to demonstrate errors that can be made in computing laboratory rate coefficients by dividing pseudo-first-order rate coefficients by [FAC] or [HOCl]; to do so ignores our findings that reactions are rarely first-order in [FAC], and that [HOCl] is not invariably the sole active chlorine species. Incorporating our findings in disinfection byproduct (DBP) control strategies should enable cost-effective control strategies (e.g., substituting coagulants such as alum for chloride-containing salts such as FeCl3).

We also developed a method (employing trimethoxybenzene) for simultaneously quenching samples containing free chlorine, while also enabling quantification of free chlorine and free bromine. The simultaneous quenching and measurement of free available chlorine and bromine confers significant advantages in DBP research.

Finally, we developed a method that allows us to simultaneously quench and quantitate active iodine species present during studies of iodination. Studies conducted to date illustrate some of the differences between iodine and other halogens. For example, although chloride ion serves as a catalyst of chlorination (by forming Cl2) and bromination (via formation of BrCl), its effectiveness of iodination reactions is much less pronounced, suggesting that ICl is not an important iodinating agent. We will be relying on this method extensively in our future studies of iodination chemistry.

In terms of broader impacts, this grant enhanced K-12 education through collaboration with the NSF-funded STEM Achievement in Baltimore Elementary Schools (SABES) program. For two years, the PI and graduate/undergraduate research assistants visited John Ruhrah Elementary/Middle each week to guide students through various STEM-related projects. The students were predominately Latino and approximately half female. In 3rd grade, specific projects (e.g., balloon cars, string telephones) familiarized students to the engineering design process. The following year, we helped the same students choose and implement a research project to benefit their community, designing devices to remove trash from water bodies. The project reinforced the reiterative nature of the design process while teaching fundamental scientific principles such as buoyancy and magnetism. Undergraduate education was also enhanced by utilization of the total organic halogen (TOX) analyzer (partially purchased by this grant) in the PI’s undergraduate laboratory class, as well as in research conducted by undergraduates in our lab.
